WRIGHT Attorney General EDWIN VAIL Assistant TAX COMMISSIONERS OF NEBRASKA The position of State Tax Commissioner was created by the Con - stitution of 1920. Prior thereto the work|\vas performed by a secretary to the State Board of Equalization and Assessment, the Tax Commis - sioner being made a member of the boai^l. Those who have served as Commissioner under the constitutional provision are: NAME COUNTY SERVED W. H. OSBORNE Ouster Apjril 25, 1921 to April 18, 1923 WM. H. SMITH Seward April 18, 1923 to Jan. 12, 1925 T. E. WILLIAMS.- Hamilton Jaji. 12 1925 to Jan. 8, 1929 HARRY W. SCOTT....Lancaster... Jan. 8, 1929 to Dec. 1, 1930 WM. H. SMITH Seward Jan. 8, 1931 to

OFFICE OF STATE TAX COMMISSIONER LINCOLN, NEBRASKA LETTER OF TRANSMITTAL December 1, 1935. Honorable R. L. Cochran, Governor of Nebraska. My dear Governor: I am handing you herewith a copy of iho annual report of tht State Board of Equalization and Assessment, and the State Tax Com - missioner for the year 1935. The valuation of the state, returned by the local assessors, and as equalized by the State Board, was found to be $2,030,243,533.00. While this is a decrease of approximately $29,000,000.00 from the valuation returned m 1934, nevertheless it is very gratifying when one considers the drouth with which the state was afflicted during the latter year, as a result of which the amount of livestock and grain on the farms was reduced to the lowest point m many years. Had it not been for this decrease, lam of the opin - ion the valuation this year would have been m excess of that found a year ago. The amount of state tax levied by the Board was only slightly m excess of that levied m 1934. Anticipated revenue from the tax on liquor, however, has been of material aid m maintaining a low levy. The proceeds from the 1935 levy is estimated at $4,363,838.GC, this figure being set forth m the resolution adopted by the Board, fix - ing 1 the levy, and published m full elsewhere m this report. There will be a slight variation shown m the table containing the footings of the tax list, as reported by the county clerks, the latter figure being the total on each individual schedule, after all corrections and addi - tions have been finally made, whereas the former figure is the estimate based upon the total valuation of the state as returned by the as - sessors, to which has been applied the levy fixed by the Board. Real estate was not re-assessed m 1935, but will be valued again m 1936. The following statement will show the percentage the various classes of property represent of the total:

All Other Property (excluding in- tangibles) 18,981,636 .009,341) 20. Total $2,030,243,533 1.000,000 From the foregoing, it is determined that farm property repre - sents 64% of the total assessed valuation of the state. The farm property classification is represented by items 1, 2, 4, 5. 6, 7, and one-half of Nos. 9 and 11. There will be found one new table in the report this year, in which is set forth the total tax levy of all the incorporated towns, the total in - cluding the amount levied for state, county, school, and municipal purposes. This statement is arranged by counties, ,and under each county head will be found a' list of all the cities and towns therein. The population of the various towns will be shown, as determined by the 1930 census, and the assessed valuation in 1935. Heretofore, a statement has shown the levies in the bounty seat towns only, but I believe this enlarged table will be of nterest and value to all the municipalities of the state. The annual meeting of county assessors was held at the Lincoln Hotel in Lincoln March 7 and 8, 1935 and was well attended. In addition thereto, the Tax Commissionel- arranged for and attended group meetings of assessors and other local officers, as follows:

STATE OF NEBRASKA ; ; Tecumseh — April 18. Five counties represented. West Point — April 25. Nine counties represented. North Platte — April 30. Eleven counties represented. Albion — May 9. Four counties represented. Hastings — May 16. Nine counties represented. A series of twelve bulletins was issued during the assessment per - iod, in which questions submitted were answered, and information of general interest to assessors imparted. In the death of Honorable W. B. Price, State Auditor, the state board has lost a valuable member, and I want to herewith recognize his splendid services the past three years. I found him always willing to cooperate and lend every aid possible in carrying on the work. He has been succeeded by Honorable Fred C. Ayres as State Auditor, whom I believe will prove an efficient member. Respectfully submitted, State Tax Commissioner.

STATE OF NEBRASKA STATEMENT No. 4 Rolling Stock Aiietsment The rolling stock assessment of the various railroads is made by the State Board of Equalization and Assessment in accordance with Section 77-616, Compiled Statutes of Nebraska for 1929. The amount so found is divided by the total number of miles, giving the total valu - ation per mile, and .this amount is multiplied by the number of miles in each city or village. This amount is then certified to the county clerk to be added to the assessment of 'terminal property which is made by the local assessor annd equalized by the State Board.
